At a time when a stock market rally has made private equity firms reluctant to take companies private for fear of overpaying, the deal illustrates how activist investors have the potential to drive corporate boards to explore such deals and accept a price that makes a leveraged buyout possible, Reuters reported.
PetSmart said BC Partners, as well as some of its fund investors, including La Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec and StepStone, signed an agreement to buy the company for $83 per share.
The buyout price represents a 39 percent premium to PetSmart's closing price of $59.81 on July 2, the day before Jana disclosed its stake and called for PetSmart to explore a sale.
A PetSmart buyout now marks the largest leveraged one of the year after a private equity consortium led by BC Partners acquired the retailer in a $8.7 billion mega-deal on Sunday.
PetSmart faced mounting investor pressure at a time when fierce competition from large retailers, including Wal-Mart Stores Inc and Amazon, is squeezing specialty stores.
Phoenix-based PetSmart, which has about 54,000 employees and operates 1,387 pet stores, said in August it would explore a potential sale of the company.
Buyout firms KKR & Co LP and Clayton, Dubilier & Rice LLC had also teamed up to bid for the company, Reuters reported last month.
Apollo Global Management LLC, another buyout firm, had also vied for PetSmart, according to people familiar with the matter.
Activist investor Jana Partners LLC began pushing for a sale after disclosing a 9.9 percent stake in PetSmart in early July.
Last month, PetSmart reported flat third-quarter net income of $92.2 million as net sales rose 2.6 percent to $1.7 billion.
Longview Asset Management, which has a 9 percent stake in PetSmart, will roll a third of its holding into the deal.
Jana paid less than $55 per share on average for its percent stake in PetSmart, according to regulatory filings.
Citigroup, Nomura, Jefferies, Barclays, and Deutsche Bank have committed to finance the acquisition with debt.
BC Partners and its partners were advised by Simpson Thacher & Bartlett LLP and Ernst & Young.
J.P. Morgan Securities LLC and Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz advised PetSmart.
Representatives for these private equity firms declined to comment.
Longview was advised by Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.
PetSmart shares on Friday closed at $77.67.
